title: Playwright Introduction Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of Playwright fundamentals

questions.question: Which company developed Playwright?
questions.explanation: Playwright was developed by Microsoft and was first released in 2020. It was created by the same team that created Puppeteer.

questions.question: Which browsers does Playwright support out of the box?
questions.explanation: Playwright supports Chromium (Chrome/Edge), Firefox, and WebKit (Safari) with a single unified API.

questions.question: Playwright automatically waits for elements to be actionable before performing actions.
questions.explanation: One of Playwright's key features is 'auto-waiting' - it automatically waits for elements to be visible, stable, and actionable before performing actions, eliminating flaky tests.

questions.question: What programming languages does Playwright support?

options.text: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Java, and C#

questions.explanation: Playwright has official client libraries for JavaScript/TypeScript, Python, Java, and C#, making it accessible to teams with different language preferences.

questions.question: What is the default timeout for Playwright actions?
questions.explanation: Playwright has a default timeout of 30 seconds for most operations. This can be configured globally or per-action.

questions.question: You need to test a single-page application (SPA) that loads content dynamically after initial page load. Which Playwright feature would be most helpful?
questions.explanation: For SPAs with dynamic content, use waitForSelector with the 'attached', 'visible', 'hidden', or 'detached' state option to wait for elements to reach the desired state.

questions.question: What is Playwright's 'codegen' tool used for?

options.text: Recording browser interactions to generate test code

questions.explanation: Playwright codegen is a CLI tool that opens a browser and records your interactions, generating clean Playwright test code that you can save and modify.

questions.question: Playwright tests can run in parallel across multiple worker processes.
questions.explanation: Playwright supports parallel test execution across multiple worker processes, significantly reducing test suite execution time.

questions.question: Which method is used to launch a browser in Playwright?
questions.explanation: To launch a browser, you use playwright.chromium.launch(), playwright.firefox.launch(), or playwright.webkit.launch() depending on which browser you need.

options.text: Navigate to example.com and click any element containing 'Learn More'
Navigate to example.com and click a button with exact text 'Learn More'
Navigate to example.com and wait for 3 seconds
This code will fail because it's missing browser launch

questions.explanation: The 'text=' selector in Playwright finds an element with the specified text. It uses fuzzy matching and will click any element containing 'Learn More'.

questions.question: What is Playwright Test Runner primarily built on?

options.text: It has its own test runner

questions.explanation: Playwright comes with its own built-in test runner called 'playwright-test' (or @playwright/test) which provides a complete testing solution with parallel execution, reporting, and fixtures.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a built-in Playwright locator strategy?
questions.explanation: Playwright provides getByText(), getByRole(), getByLabel(), getByPlaceholder(), getByAltText(), and getByTitle(). It does NOT have a built-in getByXPath() method.

questions.question: Playwright can record videos of test executions.
questions.explanation: Playwright can record videos of test executions when configured in the playwright.config.js file, which is extremely helpful for debugging failed tests.

questions.question: Your application makes an API call after a button click and displays the result. How would you test this in Playwright?

options.text: Use page.waitForTimeout() to wait for the API
Use page.waitForResponse() to wait for the API call to complete
Check if the button exists only

questions.explanation: Use page.waitForResponse() or page.waitForRequest() to properly wait for network requests/responses after interactions, ensuring the data is loaded before assertions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Playwright Trace Viewer?

options.text: To trace memory leaks in tests
To view a recording of test execution with full timeline and snapshots

questions.explanation: Playwright Trace Viewer is a GUI tool that lets you inspect test execution recordings, including screenshots, network logs, console logs, and full timeline information.

questions.question: Which command is used to install Playwright and its dependencies?
questions.explanation: npm init playwright@latest is the recommended way to set up Playwright. It installs the test runner, creates configuration files, and sets up example tests.

questions.question: Playwright can be used for API testing in addition to browser automation.
questions.explanation: Playwright includes an APIRequest context for making HTTP requests directly, allowing you to test REST APIs without a browser.

questions.question: What is the difference between page.locator() and page.$$()?

options.text: locator() returns a Locator object with auto-waiting, $$ returns raw elements
locator() only works with CSS selectors

questions.explanation: page.locator() returns a Locator object that has built-in auto-waiting and retry logic, while page.$$() returns raw DOM elements without these features.

questions.question: You want to test that a form validation message appears when submitting an empty form. Which assertion would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Using Playwright's expect() with web-first assertions like toBeVisible() is the recommended approach. It automatically waits for the element to reach the expected state.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of Playwright over Selenium for modern web applications?

options.text: Playwright is free while Selenium requires payment
Playwright has built-in auto-waiting and modern architecture for SPAs

questions.explanation: Playwright's modern architecture with auto-waiting, built-in retry logic, and native support for modern web features like shadow DOM and SPA routing makes it more reliable for testing contemporary web applications.
